title: Connecting graph of function with derivatives

content.question: The function f has the property that f(x), f’(x) and f”(x) are negative for all real values x. Which of the following could be the graph of f ?

choices.label: The answer choices are all graphs on some unscaled set of axes. This graph lies entirely under the x-axis.  The graph decreases with bound for infinitely large and small values of x.  The graph is concave down for all x and reaches a maximum at its y-intercept.

The answer choices are all graphs on some unscaled set of axes. This graph lies entirely under the x-axis.  The graph decreases for all values of x.  It is asymptotic to the x-axis for infinitely small values of x and decreases without bound for infinitely large values of x.  The graph is concave down for all x.

The answer choices are all graphs on some unscaled set of axes.  This graph lies entirely under the x-axis.  The graph increases for all values of x.  It is asymptotic to the x-axis for infinitely large values of x and decreases without bound for infinitely small values of x.  The graph is concave down for all x.

The answer choices are all graphs on some unscaled set of axes. This graph lies entirely under the x-axis.  The graph decreases for all values of x.  It is asymptotic to the x-axis for infinitely small values of x and is asymptotic to some constant for infinitely large values of x.  The graph goes from concave down to concave up somewhere in the third quadrant.

The answer choices are all graphs on some unscaled set of axes. This graph lies entirely above the x-axis.  The graph increases for all values of x.  It is asymptotic to the x-axis for infinitely small values of x and increases without bound for infinitely large values of x.  The graph is concave up for all x.

content.answer: The answer choices are all graphs on some unscaled set of axes. This graph lies entirely under the x-axis.  The graph decreases for all values of x.  It is asymptotic to the x-axis for infinitely small values of x and decreases without bound for infinitely large values of x.  The graph is concave down for all x.

topic.text: 5.9: Connecting a Function, Its First Derivative, and Its Second Derivative

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Identify how mathematical characteristics or properties of functions are related in different representations.
